complianceMapping.implementation: Istio service mesh provides automatic mTLS between all services, enforcing TLS 1.3 for all pod-to-pod communication

All data stored externally via cloud providers (S3, ADLS, GCS) with native encryption at rest. No data persisted in-cluster. Cloud storage providers handle AES-256 encryption with customer-managed or provider-managed keys
Kubernetes RBAC integrated with Kubeflow multi-tenancy. Istio authorization policies for service-level access control
Kubernetes audit logging enabled. Istio access logs configured for all services
complianceMapping.gap: Centralized log aggregation not configured. SIEM integration pending

complianceMapping.implementation: Kubernetes NetworkPolicies enforced. Istio provides service mesh segmentation with zero-trust networking
Kubernetes Secrets used for basic secret storage. Istio manages service certificates automatically
complianceMapping.gap: No external KMS/HSM integration. Secrets not encrypted with customer-managed keys
MFA needs to be configured at the identity provider level (OAuth2/OIDC integration required)

complianceMapping.implementation: Basic image scanning in CI/CD pipeline
complianceMapping.gap: Runtime vulnerability scanning not implemented. No automated remediation process

complianceMapping.implementation: Data residency fully controlled by cloud storage provider selection (S3 regions, ADLS locations, GCS regions). PV/PVC configuration enforces storage location. No data stored in-cluster ensures compliance with data sovereignty requirements

complianceMapping.gap: No incident response playbooks. No automated incident detection and response

complianceMapping.implementation: Cloud storage providers offer built-in redundancy and replication. Kubernetes stateless architecture enables quick recovery. Velero can backup cluster configuration
complianceMapping.gap: No tested DR procedures for cluster recovery. RTO/RPO not defined. Need documented recovery procedures

complianceMapping.implementation: Prometheus collects metrics from all components. Grafana provides dashboards. Istio provides distributed tracing
complianceMapping.gap: Security-specific monitoring not configured. No anomaly detection. Alert fatigue management needed

complianceMapping.implementation: Some CIS controls implemented by default in managed Kubernetes
complianceMapping.gap: Full CIS benchmark compliance not verified. Automated compliance scanning not implemented

complianceMapping.implementation: Basic pod security policies in place
complianceMapping.gap: Pod Security Standards not fully enforced. Admission controllers need configuration
No automated data deletion workflows. No consent management. No data portability features

complianceMapping.implementation: Encryption and access controls provide basic protection
complianceMapping.gap: No PHI-specific access logging. No automatic de-identification. BAA agreements not in place

strengths: No data stored in-cluster - all data externalized to cloud storage providers
Full encryption at rest via cloud provider native capabilities (S3, ADLS, GCS)
Complete data residency control through cloud storage region selection
Strong service mesh security with Istio providing mTLS and zero-trust networking
Kubernetes RBAC provides granular access control
Built-in observability with Prometheus, Grafana, and Istio tracing
Container orchestration provides good foundation for security controls
Kubeflow multi-tenancy supports isolation between teams
Stateless cluster architecture simplifies disaster recovery and compliance

criticalGaps.recommendation: Integrate with enterprise identity provider (Okta, Auth0, Keycloak) with MFA support
Deploy HashiCorp Vault or integrate with cloud KMS (AWS KMS, Azure Key Vault, GCP KMS)
Deploy or integrate with SIEM solution (Splunk, Elastic Security, Datadog)
Develop and test incident response playbooks, implement automated detection

missingItems: Data subject rights automation (access, deletion, portability)

implementedItems: Encryption at rest (cloud storage with AES-256)
missingItems: Data backup and disaster recovery procedures

implementedItems: Physical security via cloud providers (A.11 - partial)

summary.scoreCalculation: Weighted average based on priority: GDPR (45%) × 25% + HIPAA (50%) × 25% + ISO_27001 (43%) × 25% + SOC_2 (35%) × 15% + PCI_DSS (25%) × 10%

glossary.definition: General Data Protection Regulation - European Union regulation on data protection and privacy for individuals within the EU and European Economic Area
Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act - US federal law that provides data privacy and security provisions for safeguarding medical information
Protected Health Information - Any information about health status, healthcare provision, or payment that can be linked to an individual
Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard - Information security standard for organizations that handle branded credit cards
International Organization for Standardization standard that provides requirements for an information security management system (ISMS)
Service Organization Control 2 - Auditing procedure that ensures service providers securely manage data to protect interests and privacy of clients
Federal Risk and Authorization Management Program - US government-wide compliance program for cloud products and services
Department of Defense Security Requirements Guide - Guidelines for cloud service providers supporting DoD missions
Role-Based Access Control - Method of restricting system access to authorized users based on their role within an organization
Identity and Access Management - Framework of policies and technologies ensuring the right individuals access the right resources
Multi-Factor Authentication - Security system requiring multiple methods of authentication from independent categories of credentials
Security Information and Event Management - Software that provides real-time analysis of security alerts generated by applications and network hardware
Key Management Service - Cloud service that helps create and manage cryptographic keys and control their use across applications
Hardware Security Module - Physical computing device that safeguards and manages digital keys for strong authentication
Transport Layer Security - Cryptographic protocol designed to provide communications security over a computer network
Advanced Encryption Standard with 256-bit key - Symmetric encryption algorithm widely adopted as the encryption standard by the US government
Federal Information Processing Standards - US government computer security standards for cryptographic modules
Center for Internet Security - Non-profit organization that develops security benchmarks and best practices
Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures - List of publicly disclosed computer security flaws
Cardholder Data Environment - Network segment where cardholder data is stored, processed, or transmitted
Data Protection Officer - Enterprise security leadership role required by GDPR for organizations that process EU citizens' data
Static Application Security Testing - Testing methodology that analyzes source code to find security vulnerabilities
Dynamic Application Security Testing - Testing process that analyzes running applications for security vulnerabilities
Continuous Integration/Continuous Deployment - Method to frequently deliver apps by introducing automation into app development stages
National Institute of Standards and Technology - US federal agency that develops technology, metrics, and standards
